reviewText: I don`t believe this one ever got to the U.K. when i was riding the range at Saturday cinema. One word. Wonderful. My memories of serials in the early 50`s here in U.K. were Blackhawk. Possibly the best ever. Jungle Girl, Captain Video,SirLancelot,Superman,and White Eagle. Now at almost 60 years old to be able to relive those happy years once again with a serial like Red Ryder plus a TV episode with one of my favorite cowboys Rocky Lane is beyond words.The D V D transfer is very good its a treat to be able to see a good quality picture at last. I`ve had enough of poor quality slow speed  video copy`s and as for some of the material some people get away with on the net. I urge you forget the rubbish and go for D V D and make Red Ryder your first choice. Come on company`s lets have some more...
Title: N/A

reviewText: DON BARRY is the cowboy hero RED RYDER in this 12-PART SERIAL from Republic Pictures, circa 1940.  It seems there is a CROOKED BANKER who is trying to steal land from good, honest, hard-working LANDOWNERS!  So it is up to RED RYDER to save the day!  NOAH BEERY plays Ace Hanlon while TOMMY COOK plays Little Beaver!  You will THRILL to the CLIFFHANGERS in this serial, which is definitely an above-average example of the long forgotten art form!  The EXTRAS are pretty sweet this time around too, partner!  There is the PILOT for the RED RYDER TELEVISION SERIES, an interview with Don Barry himself and reproductions of LOBBY CARDS and POSTERS!  If you were not a fan way back when, you sure shooting can become one now!
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, the casting seemed perfect.  Don "Red" Barry is a far better lookalike than Wild Bill Elliot ever was.  Tommy Cook as Little Beaver is the impudent, tough little Native American kid as portrayed in the comic strip.  The Duchess is suitably tough and Ace Hanlon is as rascally as you can get.The action is terrific, with cinematic touches that maximize the pace.  I noticed expert touches such as constant body movement during "slow" expository sequences, alternating of scenes so that the actiobn is from left to right in one scene, and right to left in the next...sounds like nitpicking little details, but it all shows how lovingly made this serial is.I've heard the phrase "pulse pounding action"..well that phrase fits well.  If the chapter endings had been a bit more innovative, I would've given this five stars, but as is, it's definitely a superior serial, and arguably one of the best two western serials.red"
summary: Whether or not you ever read the strip, you'll love this!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This an enjoyable cliffhanger with some excellent character acting.Don "Red" Barry is an excellent Red Ryder.  Noah Beery as a sinister villan "enforcer" who does the bidding of an evil banker boss.  Little Beaver plays a major role and saves Red from certain disaster on numerous occasions.  This is definitely one of the better western serials with black hearted, evil villains and strong, pure of heart good guys.  Some creative endings to each chapter keep you hanging on to the edge of the cliff!
summary: One of the Better Western Cliffhangers
Title: N/A

reviewText: It is hard to watch this movie today without the haunting image of the real life Donald Barry. There were good reasons for this serial's success and Barry was set to become  a Republic Saturday regular with no reason for fans to compare him with Bill Elliot. William Lava, one of Republic's resident  geniuses, penned one of the very best western musical themes ever heard and a generation would have associated it with Don Barry, short or tall. How sad. What a pity to see people so ruled and destroyed by their own personality. So I refer the reader to the several good reviews of the Red Ryder movies on this web site.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is yet another adaptation of a popular comic strip.  Yours truly regularly read Red Ryder comic books as a teen, and this is worthy translation.  Don Barry is very good in the title role, although he really doesn't fit the comic book look of Red Ryder--Red is a tall gangly guy, and Barry is very short.  It's comical (pun intended) to see him do a little hop when he mounts his horse in order to be able to jump up that high!  Directors Witney and English couldn't stand working with Barry and his oversize ego (they called him "the midget"); apparently he constantly wanted to change things and write his own lines.  Despite this, the relationship works very well indeed on the screen.  Probably they gave him that huge hat to make him look taller.Tommy Cook plays Red's buddy Little Beaver, and he does well with the silly "Indian lingo" lines they gave him.  Noah Beery ("Overland Mail", "Zorro Rides Again") is an all-time favorite Western bad-guy, and William Farnum helps out.  Hal Taliaferro, seen in lots of serials, is Red's pal Cherokee, and Maude Pierce Allen is terrific as Red's aunt, the Duchess.  The indefatigible Davy Sharpe does the stunt work for Barry.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Adventures of Red Ryder" is a 12-chapter Republic serial released in 1940 starring Don Barry, billed as Don "Red" Barry, directed by William Witney and John English.Red is up against a gang of crooks trying to drive the ranchers off their land by any means, because known only to crooked banker Calvin Drake (Harry Worth) and saloon owner Ace Hanlon (Noah Beery) the Western Pacific railroad is coming through, and the ranch land will be worth a fortune.  Nothing unique in the plot, but "B" westerns and serials were Republic's main business, and their expertise shows.  In addition to good action, photography, film editing and a fine musical score by Cy Feuer, the casting of Barry in the title role was successful, despite his short stature.  Red's hot-headed nature, often mentioned in the feature films, is portrayed far better in this serial, and child actor Tommy Cook makes a believable Little Beaver.  Noah Beery is in a role familiar from earlier serials "The Devil Horse" and "Fighting with Kit Carson," an outwardly respectable citizen who is one of the main crooks.  Red gets additional help from his aunt, The Dutchess (Maude Pierce Allen) and Cherokee Sims (Hal Taliaferro).  Beth Andrews (Vivian Coe), daughter of the slain sheriff occasionally needs to be rescued by Red, though she is otherwise seldom seen.  The replacement sheriff, Dade (Carlton Young) is one of Hanlon's gang, which also includes One-Eye Chapin (Bob Kortman), Slade (Reed Howes), Shark (Ray Teal) and Bart Wade (Ken Terrell).  The plot moves along quite well, and the cliffhangers involve a variety of perils, though all quite familiar to fans of serials and "B" westerns.VCI's edition, # 8256 on a double-layer DVD is an older release and their website now lists it as being on a DVD-R.  The source was a 16mm reduction print, with the focus going a little soft in the corners of the frame, noticed mostly in the opening credits, and the sound is a little deficient in high-frequency content, but neither is much of a problem for normal viewing.  The image is reasonably sharp and clear in most chapters.  There are some minor scratches, "white dirt" and similar ills common to existing prints, and the gray scale is good if not outstanding.  Unfortunately the print VCI had for Chapter Four was worse than the others, with excess contrast causing some faces to go blank, and little is visible in the darker scenes.  Some patching was done using the footage leading up to the cliffhanger from the end of Chapter Three, though the transition into the poorer print is obvious.  They also used the opening credits from Chapter Three, changing only the chapter title and not the "recap" text.  But the rest of the serial is fine.  "Bonus" features are plentiful, including the original trailer, an interview with Don "Red" Barry, an unsold Red Ryder television pilot starring Allan "Rocky" Lane, "bios" of Don "Red" Barry, Tommy Cook, Noah Beery, John English, William Witney and Vivian Coe, and a "Picture Gallery" with lobby cards for seven feature "Red Ryder" films and about 30 images from comic books, including a few covers.The use of DVD-R media is unfortunate, since many players will not work with double-layer "burned" discs, but the change was doubtless to keep this older release available.  Check the player's instruction manual for "DVD-R DL" and "DVD+R DL" as compatible types.  When watched, with a day or so between chapters, this is an excellent western serial, well worth tolerating the flaws of the film print used for Chapter Four.
summary: First Red Ryder film is a fine serial
